entry.title: By: Chuck Boyce
entry.content:
I said this on Brent’s blog, but I thought I’d paste it here, too in the rare chance someone doesn’t also visit Brent’s site.

—

The best thing that ever happened to me was NOT being renewed as a Digital Media MVP in 2009(I used to be a SQL MVP but by some stroke of insanity I asked Microsoft if I could transfer my MVP to Digital Media).

I was pissed at first as that same year my MVP Lead told me I was doing things that were way ahead of anyone else. Several of my sites crashed (I had no backups‚Ä¶horror) and a new Lead was re-assigned to me and I didn‚Äôt take the time to explain. Quite frankly I was in a personal economic tailspin and the last thing I cared about was the triviality of a Digital Media MVP.

But when I got perspective, I realized that I was FREE. I could now say ‚ÄúMicrosft abandoned Silverlight‚Äù (gasp) or ‚ÄúI love ubuntu‚Äù, etc., etc., etc.

Being an MVP should not mean you are one of the few people that own a Zune, Kin, or say ‚ÄúBing‚Äù when you really mean ‚ÄúGoogle‚Äù. It should mean what it says it means ‚Äì you are a respected, recognized, credible expert that helps people. You shouldn‚Äôt have to leave your opinions at the door.

entry.title: By: Argenis Fernandez
entry.content:
I left a comment on Brent’s blog, and I feel I need to make another one here, too.

While I love the MVP community, I feel they are the only ones with enough power to drive product decisions outside of Microsoft. If MVPs are tame, constructive criticism will never get to the PMs and middle-managers at Microsoft that can make a difference. I, for one, expect MVPs to be very vocal, even if their opinion is not popular.

entry.title: By: Steve Jones
entry.content:
I had similar thoughts today as well: http://www.sqlservercentral.com/articles/Editorial/101453/

Good post, Ted, and I agree. It doesn’t make sense to rant and rave about issues, when there are more productive ways to make your point.

I took this differently than Brent. Pointing out flaws, or noting decisions seem to not make sense, as Brent did in his post, isn’t flaming the product, development team, or company. Calling them (devs, managers, etc) stupid for not changing something is. All too often I do see people ranting or flaming and making it personal when it isn’t. It’s a business decision, great one or poor one, that was made. You can seek to influence, and you can do so loudly, but you don’t need to do so rudely.
